title: Bartering second portion produce
vignette: In the main city community assistant says to Judah: “Here is set-aside portion wine; give me oil in exchange.”

options.text: Barter is fine – equal-value swap benefits both.
Forbidden; set-aside portion produce may only be given as a free gift.

title: Proposing Marriage with livestock portion proceeds
vignette: A man tries to proposing marriage a woman with an perfect set-aside portion-calf.

options.text: Valid – the calf has monetary worth.
Invalid; property with special status may not be used for marriage.

title: Who owns the hide?
vignette: Set-aside portion-coins buy an animal for food; after ritual preparation the hide is worth more than the meat.

options.text: Hide is ordinary; owner keeps the profit.
Hide is special status; its value must also be eaten in the main city.

title: Illicit purchases with set aside a portion money
vignette: Mistakenly buying water or salt with set-aside portion-coins.

options.text: Deal stands; use the goods in the main city anyway.
Deal void; restore the coins’ special status and dispose of the goods.

title: Buying enslaved persons or homeland with set aside a portion-coins
vignette: Shimon purchases a field using second portion money.

options.text: Transaction valid – treat homeland as investment for future meals.
Prohibited; must earmark an equivalent sum for food in the main city.

title: Anointing with set aside a portion oil
vignette: May a traveler use second portion olive oil as body lotion in the main city?

options.text: Yes; oil counts as ‘eat, drink, or anoint’.
No; set-aside portion must be eaten, not smeared.

title: Paying the porter
vignette: Owner asks a friend to carry set-aside portion produce to the main city. May he reward him with a share of that produce?

options.text: Yes; fair compensation for labour.
No; giving a share turns set-aside portion into barter.

title: Swapping with a non-observant vendor
vignette: A traveler with set-aside portion-coins wants to buy produce from an unlearned person (*unlearned person*).

options.text: Permitted – treat coins like cash; buyer just eats in uncontaminated.
Forbidden – risk of ceremonially contaminated undermines special status.

title: Taking set aside a portion produce out of The Main City
vignette: Left-over figs already inside the city – may the traveler haul them back home?

options.text: Allowed; intent to return suffices.
Disallowed; once inside, produce is ‘locked in’.

title: Produce that only passed through the city
vignette: Crates of finished grain entered the main city in transit and left. Does their set-aside portion now have to be eaten there?

options.text: Yes; school of Shammai – entry alone creates the obligation.
No; school of Hillel – owner may exchange and eat anywhere.

title: Contaminated set aside a portion inside vs. outside
vignette: second portion fruit becomes contaminated. Where must the exchange money be consumed?

options.text: exchange and eat within the main city (except severe outside contamination).
exchange and eat outside (except light contamination inside).

title: Does the wine-jar become special status?
vignette: Merchant sells sealed jars of set-aside portion-wine. Do the empty jars acquire special status?

options.text: Yes; vessel value joins the wine.
No; only the contents are special status.

title: Father exchanges a minor’s set aside a portion
vignette: A father exchanges his young son’s second portion produce. Must he add the standard one-fifth surcharge?

options.text: Yes; treat the child’s set-aside portion like one’s own (another specific wise person).
No; surcharge applies only when exchanging your own produce (the first opinion holder).

title: Coin-for-coin Exchange to avoid the surcharge
vignette: A traveler exchanges small-denomination set-aside portion coins for one large coin, mainly to dodge the extra one-fifth payment.

options.text: Permitted; any exchange that lightens the load is valid (The wise people).
Forbidden if the aim is to evade the surcharge (a specific wise person).
